brief_description: This study will characterize the human maternal microbiome and host response profiles associated with term and preterm births and identify features of each that are predicitive of preterm labor and delivery
brief_title: Exploring the human maternal microbiome and its contribution to preterm birth
description: Preterm births occur in 12 percent of pregnancies. Preterm infants are at risk for long term health problems such as impaired hearing and vision, cerebral palsy and developmental delays. This study will characterize the human maternal microbiome and host response profiles associated with term and preterm births and identify features of each that are predicitive of preterm labor and delivery
hypothesis: Pregnancy-associated microbiome does not differ between term and pre-term births
objectives: Characterize the pregnancy-associated human microbiome of term and pre-term births,  identify human microbiome features predictive of spontaneous pre-term labor and birth
official_title: Exploring the human maternal microbiome and its contribution to preterm birth

arm.description: Pregnancy ended was a result of fetal demise
arm.name: Fetal Demise

personnel.organization: March of Dimes Prematurity Research Center at Stanford University School of Medicine
personnel.site_name: March of Dimes Prematurity Research Center at Stanford University School of Medicine

pubmed.title: Temporal and spatial variation of the human microbiota during pregnancy.
pubmed.journal: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A.

race.race: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander
